title: Quiz 4: Neonate Physiology & Assessment
topicName: Unit Three Part One: Labour and Puerperium
description: Normal newborn vital signs, Apgar scoring, and immediate neonatal assessment

questions.question: What is the normal respiratory rate for a newborn?
questions.explanation: The normal respiratory rate for a newborn is 30-60 breaths per minute. Newborns breathe more rapidly than adults due to higher metabolic demands and smaller lung capacity.
questions.hint: Newborns breathe faster than adults due to higher metabolic needs.

questions.question: What is the normal heart rate range for a newborn?
questions.explanation: The normal heart rate for a newborn is 100-160 beats per minute. Heart rate may vary with activity, crying, or sleep states. Rates outside this range may indicate distress.
questions.hint: Newborn heart rates are typically higher than adult rates.

questions.question: Newborns are obligate nose breathers.
questions.explanation: True. Newborns are obligate nose breathers, meaning they prefer to breathe through their nose rather than their mouth. This is important for breastfeeding as it allows them to breathe while nursing.

questions.question: Which of the following are components of the Apgar score? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The Apgar score evaluates five criteria: Appearance (skin color), Pulse (heart rate), Grimace (reflex irritability), Activity (muscle tone), and Respiration (breathing effort). Blood pressure is not included.
questions.hint: Apgar is an acronym for the five criteria assessed.

questions.question: Match each Apgar component with its assessment:
questions.explanation: Apgar components: A-Appearance (skin color), P-Pulse (heart rate), G-Grimace (reflex irritability), A-Activity (muscle tone), R-Respiration (breathing effort). Each is scored 0-2.
questions.hint: Remember the mnemonic APGAR for the five criteria.

questions.question: The Apgar score is typically assessed at ___BLANK___ and ___BLANK___ minutes after birth.
questions.explanation: The Apgar score is typically assessed at 1 and 5 minutes after birth. A score of 7-10 is considered normal, 4-6 is moderately depressed, and 0-3 is severely depressed.
questions.hint: These are the standard times for initial and follow-up assessment.

questions.question: What is the normal body temperature range for a newborn?
questions.explanation: The normal body temperature for a newborn is 36.5-37.5°C (97.7-99.5°F). Newborns are at higher risk for hypothermia due to their large surface area-to-body weight ratio.
questions.hint: Newborns lose heat easily due to their body structure.

questions.question: What is the normal birth weight range for a term infant?
questions.explanation: The normal birth weight range for a term infant is 2500-4000 grams (5.5-8.8 lbs). Infants weighing less than 2500 grams are considered low birth weight.
questions.hint: Low birth weight is defined as less than 2500 grams.

questions.question: An Apgar score of 8 at 5 minutes indicates a healthy newborn with no concerns.
questions.explanation: True. An Apgar score of 7-10 at 5 minutes indicates a healthy newborn with no concerns. Scores of 4-6 indicate moderate depression, and scores of 0-3 indicate severe depression requiring resuscitation.

questions.question: What is the definition of low birth weight (LBW)?
questions.explanation: Low birth weight (LBW) is defined as birth weight less than 2500 grams. Very low birth weight (VLBW) is less than 1500 grams, and extremely low birth weight (ELBW) is less than 1000 grams.
questions.hint: This threshold is used internationally to classify newborns.
